Comedy Club Started at JHU
A comedy club featuring
professional acts on the college
circuit will make its debut at
Hopkins Thursday. The club,
which will be called "The
at
Paradox—Comedy
Hopkins" is being sponsored
by the HOP Social Committee.
The Paradox has been
designed to provide a much
needed social outlet at
Hopkins:"comedy," according
to Mike Vogelbaum, who has
organized the first show.
Featured at Thursday evening's show will be Tony Perkins
(Master of Ceremonies), Ed
Wyzinskie, Dan Rosen, and
Andy Evans. All of these corn-

edians regularly appear at comedy clubs in major cities, such
as the Improv in New York,
and the Charm City Comedy
Club in Baltimore. Rosen and
Evans were also both voted the
top comedians in Washington,
D.C. last year.
"Evans helped me put this
show together, and plans are
already in the works for the
next show," Vogelbaum said.
The next show is tentatively
planned for the first week in
December.
There will be two shows
Thursday night: the first at 8:00
p.m. and the second at 10:30
p.m. The doors wil open at 7:30

p.m. for the first show. Admission to each show will be 50
cents, which includes free admission to the RAT after the
show.
A variety of non-alcoholic
drinks will be sold at the shows.
"Other schools, such as Dartmouth, established dessert
theaters with non-alcoholic
drinks to provide new outlets
when the drinking age increased. I feel that a comedy would
be best at Hopkins. Students
here tend to take things a little
too seriously sometimes; people
need a chance to laugh a little
more," Vogelbaum said.

by Dave Battleman
On Thursday, October 24, a
journalism career seminar was
sponsored by the Student
Councils' Committee on Career
Advising and Placement. Arnold Isaacs, staff reporter for
The Evening Sun, John Yardly, book reviewer and columnist for The Washington Post
and Gwinn Owens, Op-Ed
editor also for The Evening
Sun, conducted an open forum
in order to discuss the present
state of journalism.
The "journalistic glut," the
overwhelming abundance of
ambitious
young
and
unemployed journalists, was
the focus of their presentation.
"Over the last twenty years,
journalism has transcended into a middle class profession,"
commented Isaacs. As a result,
the stagnant journalistic field
has become increasingly crowded and highly competitive.
"Everyone wanted to
become a 'Woodward and
Bernstein,' " Yardley added.
"Journalism soon became an
alternative to Law School."
Obtaining an immediate
major
a

on
metropolitan newspaper today
with just a liberal arts degree
has become almost impossible.
"Even the best and the
brightest individuals only have
a slim chance to break into the
field." continued Yardley.
A degree in journalism from

a school highly accredited for
journalism, such as Columbia
University or Northwestern
University, is essential. "No
longer will the paper mold a
good writer into a reporter," he
added. "Protracted training is
essential."
"Some neophytes do land
jobs—talent does get recognized," Owens remarked. Talent,
however, sometimes is not
enough.
Luck is also a critical factor.
Owens continued, "Being in
the right place at the right time
can sometimes mean the difference between success and
failure."
Isaacs also conceded, "There
probably are jobs out there but
publication and experience are
essential to get them."
There are several possible
routes from which to obtain
"publication and experience."
Owens, who began his career
on a small Providence journal,
feels a small local paper is an
excellent opportunity to expose
oneself to all the facets of journalism from reporting to production. "And as one gains experience and publication, one
can slowly move upward to
larger papers."
Freelancing for major papers
or working for a wire service,
although not lucrative, is also
another way to gain necessary
experience and to get established within the industry.

Continuing Erosion
The Panel on the General Professional
Education of the Physician and College
Preparation for Medicine recently issued a
forty-eight page report entitled, "Physicians
for the Twenty-First Century." The report
is the result of three years of interviews with
students and educators concerning the effectiveness of premedical and medical education in this country. The panel found that
there is an "urgent need for improvement"
in providing a general basis of knowledge for
pre-med and medical students.
Dr. Steven Muller, panel chairman and
president of the Johns Hopkins University,
commented,"We perceive a continuing erosion of general education for physicians, an
erosion that has not been arrested but is instead accelerating."
We agree, but such analysis should not be
restricted to premedical and medical
students, or even to preprofessional students.
Every student should have a broad-based
education and should be encouraged to participate in independent learning outside of
his major field of study.
This philosophy is sound but it is unlikely that any new developments will be introduced until some time in the future. We
must currently concentrate on strengthening
existing resources to accomplish these goals.
Interest in the Intersession program at
Johns Hopkins has been suffering an unfortunate decline over the past few years. The
average enrollment in Intersession courses is
approximately 19%, with over half of the
students participating in research or independent study. This fact is surprising since other

schools with non-mandatory Intersessionlike programs, such as Oberlin and
Hamilton, can boast enrollments of over
7007o. It is also disheartening, since Intersession is a period in which students may explore novel subjects without the pressure of
the traditional semester system.
The Committee on Undergraduate Studies
has suggested that the weakness of the
Hopkins program may be traced to two
related causes.
"The first is that the program has
historically received no commitment, dollarwise or energywise, from the University, and
so is dependent entirely on the altruism of
faculty or the persuasiveness of undergraduates for its academic composition.
"The second, directly derived from the
first, is that students' attitudes are so
negative about the current program that they
are inclined to look upon Intersession more
as a burden than an opportunity."
Thus, the Johns Hopkins University is
failing to take advantage of a resource which
could potentially alleviate "the continuing
erosion of general education."
The program must be strengthened. Professors should be paid for courses they teach.
Assistant professors should be required to
teach Intersession courses and the administration should take such activity into
account when determining tenure. Basic
survey courses as well as upper division
courses should be made more available.
Perhaps then enough interest will be
generated in the program to defend its
existence.

by Skip Collins
Scientists at the School of
Medicine have recently made
some important advances in the
production of monoclonal antibodies. These are substances
with enormous potential in the
treatment of a wide range of
diseases.
The new production method
was developed by Solomon H.
Snyder, M.D., director of
neuroscience, Matthew M.S.

neuroscience, Tian Yow Tsong,
Ph.D., associate professor of
physiological chemistry, Lynda
D. Hester, neuroscience technician, and Mary Conrad and
Stephen Strittmatter, students
at the School of Medicine.
Monoclonal antibodies are
produced by cells that scientists
engineer by fusing two types of
cells. These are B lymphocytes,
B-cells for short, and myeloma
cells. B-cells are the body's own
disease-fighting white blood
cells. Myeloma cells are cancer
cells. The fused cells are called
"hybridomas."
Normal B-cells continually
patrol the body, searching for
disease-causing organisms.
When they encounter such an
invader, they produce antibodies, proteins that bind to

substances on the invader's surface, immobilizing the
organism and tagging it for
later destruction by other
disease-fighting cells.
The hybridoma also produces antibodies; due to its
tumor cell parentage, it can do
so in much greater quantities.
Another advantage of the
hybridoma is that it can be
tailored to produce only one
kind of antibody. This facilitates the identification or
destruction of minute quantities
of a foreign organism or toxin

in the body.
Scientists hope to be able to
attach anti-cancer drugs to
monoclonals. The antibodies
would then be able to fight the
tumor cells in the body while
sparing healthy, normal ones.
Before the development of
this new method of production,
hybridomas were made by
coating the parent B and
myeloma cells with polyethylene glycol which makes the
cells "sticky" and weakens
their surrounding membranes.

Mosley Returns to Public Health
W. Henry Mosley, M.D.,
M.P.H., a worldwide authority on population and infectious
disease, will return to Hopkins
School of Public Health to
become the first director of a
new institute dedicated to international health programs.
Mosley, who for the past
three years was program director for the Ford Foundation's
South East Asia Regional Office in Indonesia, also will
become chairman of the
School's Department of
Population Dynamics, which
he first headed in the 1970's.
The appointments, effective
January 1, underscore a commitment to continuing and
strengthening the School's position as a leader in international
health.
"Mosley is one of the leading
figures in the field of international health today," says D.A.
Henderson, M.D., M.P.H.,
dean of the School, in announcing the appointments."He has
an unparalleled breadth of experience in academic and practical aspects of international
health and population, issues
Since leaving Hopkins in 1977,
he has worked in Bangladesh,
Kenya, and Indonesia."
Early in his career, Mosley
established his reputation in international health as head of
the epidemiology division of the
SEATO Cholera Research
Dacca,
in
Laboratory
Bangladesh. While there, he
began pioneering research in
cholera vaccines and collected
extensive data later used for
population studies.
In 1971, Mosley left Dacca to
become chairman of the

Department of Populatiou
Dynamics and direct Hopkins'
Population Center. He returned to Bangladesh in 1977 to
direct the Cholera Research
Laboratory.
The newly created institute
will facilitate the integration of
research and educational programs involving more than 30
faculty members concerned
with nutrition, population,
health care delivery in developing nations and prevention and
treatment of infectious diseases
of the tropics.
"The School has been concerned with international health
affairs since its beginning,"
Dean Henderson says. "It leads
academic institutions in the
United States in the number of
faculty members engaged in
problems of the developing
world and has trained many
world leaders in the health
field."
Mosley will hold joint appointments in the Departments
of International Health and Immunology and Infectious
Diseases at the School. As
Chairman of the population
dynamics department, he will
succeed John F. Kantner,
Ph.D., who will continue his
research and teaching. This
year Professor Kantner is on
leave in India with U.S. Agency for International Development's Joint Career Corps.
The Department of Population Dynamics and its Population Center conduct research in
reproductive biology; design,
create, and assess family planning programs worldwide; and
study trends and consequences

of teenage pregnancies in the
United States.
The School also is home for
the Population Information
Program (PIP), a major source
of information on family planning, contraception techniques,
and primary health care for
developing countries. PIP
prepares and distributes almost
1 million publications annually, in five languages.
Mosley was a visiting professor at the Population Studies
and Research Institute at the
University of Nairobi in Kenya
from 1979 to 1981, before
assuming his duties with the
Ford Foundation. He also served as senior associate of the
Population Council during
those two years.
Mosley has been a consultant
for the World Health Organization, the National Academy of
Sciences, the U.S. Senate,
Planned Parenthood, the U.S.
Agency for International
Development, the American
Public Health Association, the
National Institutes of Health
and the International Union of
Nutrition Sciences.
The author of nearly 100 articles, he has received many
honors and awards, including
the U.S. Public Health Service's Meritorious Service
Medal.
Born in China, Mosley
received his medical degree
from the University of
Oklahoma in 1959 and completed his internship and
residency at Hopkins Hospital
in 1964. In 1965, he received his
master of public health degree
from Hopkins School of Public
Health.

It is not surprising that in the
course of this year's hectic campaigning for the _presidential
office the two major candidates, Walter Mondale and
Ronald Reagan, should coincidentally schedule a particular
city in a given region of the
country in their quest for capturing yet another politically
important block of voters. Such
a potentially explosive situation
actually developed just a short
time ago, after the last debate,
in Las Vegas, Nevada. There
have been no reports by any
part of the news media of this
rather bizarre encounter
because both campaign staffs
planned in advance elaborate
cover-up ploys to allow their
respective candidates to enjoy a
much needed day of mental
relaxation (it had been eight
grueling days of serious campaigning since Sunday's debate)
as well as to engage in a little
stumping among those wild and
wealthy voters who claim some
sort of residence in Nevada.
The relaxing and stumping,
though, were done completely
undercover, to avoid local
media attention, while official
statements were released to the
press informing us that 1)President Reagan was very busy
making crucial policy decisions
in the White House and was not
to be disturbed ("It's fun to be
on T.V., but sometimes you
have to be a President, too),

and that 2) Walter Mondale
was in Minnesota, sick in bed
with the Norwegian Flu.
The disguises that had to be
worn in Las Vegas posed no
problems for either candidate:
Ronnie merely had to refrain
from applying his Grecian
fromula for a couple days and
Walter, of course, never travels
anywhere without his make-up
man. An old wig and some
clothes he borrowed from
Gerry completed the former
vice-president's disguise. When
asked by a staff aid why he
chose to masquerade as a
woman, Mondale replied, "I'm
practicing for Halloween."

by Dave Battleman
On Thursday, October 24, a
journalism career seminar was
sponsored by the Student
Councils' Committee on Career
Advising and Placement. Arnold Isaacs, staff reporter for
The Evening Sun, John Yardly, book reviewer and columnist for The Washington Post
and Gwinn Owens, Op-Ed
editor also for The Evening
Sun, conducted an open forum
in order to discuss the present
state of journalism.
The "journalistic glut," the
overwhelming abundance of
ambitious
young
and
unemployed journalists, was
the focus of their presentation.
"Over the last twenty years,
journalism has transcended into a middle class profession,"
commented Isaacs. As a result,
the stagnant journalistic field
has become increasingly crowded and highly competitive.
"Everyone wanted to
become a 'Woodward and
Bernstein,' " Yardley added.
"Journalism soon became an
alternative to Law School."
Obtaining an immediate
major
a
position
on
metropolitan newspaper today
with just a liberal arts degree
has become almost impossible.
"Even the best and the
brightest individuals only have
a slim chance to break into the
field." continued Yardley.
A degree in journalism from

a school highly accredited for
journalism, such as Columbia
University or Northwestern
University, is essential. "No
longer will the paper mold a
good writer into a reporter," he
added. "Protracted training is
essential."
"Some neophytes do land
jobs—talent does get recognized," Owens remarked. Talent,
however, sometimes is not
enough.
Luck is also a critical factor.
Owens continued, "Being in
the right place at the right time
can sometimes mean the difference between success and
failure."
Isaacs also conceded, "There
probably are jobs out there but
publication and experience are
essential to get them."
There are several possible
routes from which to obtain
"publication and experience."
Owens, who began his career
on a small Providence journal,
feels a small local paper is an
excellent opportunity to expose
oneself to all the facets of journalism from reporting to production. "And as one gains experience and publication, one
can slowly move upward to
larger papers."
Freelancing for major papers
or working for a wire service,
although not lucrative, is also
another way to gain necessary
experience and to get established within the industry.

Continuing Erosion
The Panel on the General Professional
Education of the Physician and College
Preparation for Medicine recently issued a
forty-eight page report entitled, "Physicians
for the Twenty-First Century." The report
is the result of three years of interviews with
students and educators concerning the effectiveness of premedical and medical education in this country. The panel found that
there is an "urgent need for improvement"
in providing a general basis of knowledge for
pre-med and medical students.
Dr. Steven Muller, panel chairman and
president of the Johns Hopkins University,
commented,"We perceive a continuing erosion of general education for physicians, an
erosion that has not been arrested but is instead accelerating."
We agree, but such analysis should not be
restricted to premedical and medical
students, or even to preprofessional students.
Every student should have a broad-based
education and should be encouraged to participate in independent learning outside of
his major field of study.
This philosophy is sound but it is unlikely that any new developments will be introduced until some time in the future. We
must currently concentrate on strengthening
existing resources to accomplish these goals.
Interest in the Intersession program at
Johns Hopkins has been suffering an unfortunate decline over the past few years. The
average enrollment in Intersession courses is
approximately 19%, with over half of the
students participating in research or independent study. This fact is surprising since other

schools with non-mandatory Intersessionlike programs, such as Oberlin and
Hamilton, can boast enrollments of over
7007o. It is also disheartening, since Intersession is a period in which students may explore novel subjects without the pressure of
the traditional semester system.
The Committee on Undergraduate Studies
has suggested that the weakness of the
Hopkins program may be traced to two
related causes.
"The first is that the program has
historically received no commitment, dollarwise or energywise, from the University, and
so is dependent entirely on the altruism of
faculty or the persuasiveness of undergraduates for its academic composition.
"The second, directly derived from the
first, is that students' attitudes are so
negative about the current program that they
are inclined to look upon Intersession more
as a burden than an opportunity."
Thus, the Johns Hopkins University is
failing to take advantage of a resource which
could potentially alleviate "the continuing
erosion of general education."
The program must be strengthened. Professors should be paid for courses they teach.
Assistant professors should be required to
teach Intersession courses and the administration should take such activity into
account when determining tenure. Basic
survey courses as well as upper division
courses should be made more available.
Perhaps then enough interest will be
generated in the program to defend its
existence.

Antibody Production Stimulated by "Knocking"
by Skip Collins
Scientists at the School of
Medicine have recently made
some important advances in the
production of monoclonal antibodies. These are substances
with enormous potential in the
treatment of a wide range of
diseases.
The new production method
was developed by Solomon H.
Snyder, M.D., director of
neuroscience, Matthew M.S.
Lo,Ph.D., research associate in
neuroscience, Tian Yow Tsong,
Ph.D., associate professor of
physiological chemistry, Lynda
D. Hester, neuroscience technician, and Mary Conrad and
Stephen Strittmatter, students
at the School of Medicine.
Monoclonal antibodies are
produced by cells that scientists
engineer by fusing two types of
cells. These are B lymphocytes,
B-cells for short, and myeloma
cells. B-cells are the body's own
disease-fighting white blood
cells. Myeloma cells are cancer
cells. The fused cells are called
"hybridomas."
Normal B-cells continually
patrol the body, searching for
disease-causing organisms.
When they encounter such an
invader, they produce antibodies, proteins that bind to

substances on the invader's surface, immobilizing the
organism and tagging it for
later destruction by other
disease-fighting cells.
The hybridoma also produces antibodies; due to its
tumor cell parentage, it can do
so in much greater quantities.
Another advantage of the
hybridoma is that it can be
tailored to produce only one
kind of antibody. This facilitates the identification or
destruction of minute quantities
of a foreign organism or toxin

in the body.
Scientists hope to be able to
attach anti-cancer drugs to
monoclonals. The antibodies
would then be able to fight the
tumor cells in the body while
sparing healthy, normal ones.
Before the development of
this new method of production,
hybridomas were made by
coating the parent B and
myeloma cells with polyethylene glycol which makes the
cells "sticky" and weakens
their surrounding membranes.

Mosley Returns to Public Health
W. Henry Mosley, M.D.,
M.P.H., a worldwide authority on population and infectious
disease, will return to Hopkins
School of Public Health to
become the first director of a
new institute dedicated to international health programs.
Mosley, who for the past
three years was program director for the Ford Foundation's
South East Asia Regional Office in Indonesia, also will
become chairman of the
School's Department of
Population Dynamics, which
he first headed in the 1970's.
The appointments, effective
January 1, underscore a commitment to continuing and
strengthening the School's position as a leader in international
health.
"Mosley is one of the leading
figures in the field of international health today," says D.A.
Henderson, M.D., M.P.H.,
dean of the School, in announcing the appointments."He has
an unparalleled breadth of experience in academic and practical aspects of international
health and population, issues
Since leaving Hopkins in 1977,
he has worked in Bangladesh,
Kenya, and Indonesia."
Early in his career, Mosley
established his reputation in international health as head of
the epidemiology division of the
SEATO Cholera Research
Dacca,
in
Laboratory
Bangladesh. While there, he
began pioneering research in
cholera vaccines and collected
extensive data later used for
population studies.
In 1971, Mosley left Dacca to
become chairman of the

Department of Populatiou
Dynamics and direct Hopkins'
Population Center. He returned to Bangladesh in 1977 to
direct the Cholera Research
Laboratory.
The newly created institute
will facilitate the integration of
research and educational programs involving more than 30
faculty members concerned
with nutrition, population,
health care delivery in developing nations and prevention and
treatment of infectious diseases
of the tropics.
"The School has been concerned with international health
affairs since its beginning,"
Dean Henderson says. "It leads
academic institutions in the
United States in the number of
faculty members engaged in
problems of the developing
world and has trained many
world leaders in the health
field."
Mosley will hold joint appointments in the Departments
of International Health and Immunology and Infectious
Diseases at the School. As
Chairman of the population
dynamics department, he will
succeed John F. Kantner,
Ph.D., who will continue his
research and teaching. This
year Professor Kantner is on
leave in India with U.S. Agency for International Development's Joint Career Corps.
The Department of Population Dynamics and its Population Center conduct research in
reproductive biology; design,
create, and assess family planning programs worldwide; and
study trends and consequences

of teenage pregnancies in the
United States.
The School also is home for
the Population Information
Program (PIP), a major source
of information on family planning, contraception techniques,
and primary health care for
developing countries. PIP
prepares and distributes almost
1 million publications annually, in five languages.
Mosley was a visiting professor at the Population Studies
and Research Institute at the
University of Nairobi in Kenya
from 1979 to 1981, before
assuming his duties with the
Ford Foundation. He also served as senior associate of the
Population Council during
those two years.
Mosley has been a consultant
for the World Health Organization, the National Academy of
Sciences, the U.S. Senate,
Planned Parenthood, the U.S.
Agency for International
Development, the American
Public Health Association, the
National Institutes of Health
and the International Union of
Nutrition Sciences.
The author of nearly 100 articles, he has received many
honors and awards, including
the U.S. Public Health Service's Meritorious Service
Medal.
Born in China, Mosley
received his medical degree
from the University of
Oklahoma in 1959 and completed his internship and
residency at Hopkins Hospital
in 1964. In 1965, he received his
master of public health degree
from Hopkins School of Public
Health.

course of this year's hectic campaigning for the _presidential
office the two major candidates, Walter Mondale and

city in a given region of the

important block of voters. Such
a potentially explosive situation
actually developed just a short
time ago, after the last debate,
in Las Vegas, Nevada. There
have been no reports by any
part of the news media of this
rather bizarre encounter
because both campaign staffs
planned in advance elaborate
cover-up ploys to allow their
respective candidates to enjoy a
much needed day of mental
relaxation (it had been eight
grueling days of serious campaigning since Sunday's debate)
as well as to engage in a little
stumping among those wild and
wealthy voters who claim some
sort of residence in Nevada.

undercover, to avoid local
media attention, while official
statements were released to the
press informing us that 1)President Reagan was very busy
making crucial policy decisions

to be disturbed ("It's fun to be
on T.V., but sometimes you
have to be a President, too),

and that 2) Walter Mondale
was in Minnesota, sick in bed
with the Norwegian Flu.

worn in Las Vegas posed no

fromula for a couple days and

practicing for Halloween."
